content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.Answer the following questions about hydroxylamine, <math alttext="N H 2 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></math>.(a) Complete the Lewis electron-dot diagram of the <math alttext="N H 2 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></math> molecule in the box below, including all bonding and nonbonding valence electrons.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.Answer the following questions about hydroxylamine, <math alttext="N H 2 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></math>.(a) Complete the Lewis electron-dot diagram of the <math alttext="N H 2 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></math> molecule in the box below, including all bonding and nonbonding valence electrons.

(b) Hydroxylamine, <math alttext="N H 2 O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>, is a weak base. Write the balanced net ionic equation for the reaction that occurs when <math alttext="N H 2 O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> and <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> are combined.

A student is preparing to titrate a <math alttext="N H 2 O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> solution with <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>. To prepare for the titration, the student places the <math alttext="N H 2 O H" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></math> solution into an Erlenmeyer flask. (c) The titration procedure instructs the student to prepare <math alttext="100.00 milliliters" overflow="scroll"> <mn>100.00</mn> <mo> </mo> <mtext>mL</mtext> </math> of a <math alttext="0.1000 molar H C l" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0.1000</mn> <mo> </mo> <mi>M</mi> <mo> </mo> <mi>HCl</mi> </math> solution. The stock solution available is <math alttext="0.5604 molar H C l" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0.5604</mn> <mo> </mo> <mi>M</mi> <mo> </mo> <mi>HCl</mi> </math>. Calculate the volume, in liters, of stock solution required for the dilution.

(d) Using the following choices, identify the glassware that should be used to deliver the <math alttext="H C l, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> with the greatest precision. Circle your choice and provide a brief justification.

(e) The student titrates a <math alttext="25.00 milliliter" overflow="scroll"> <mn>25.00</mn> <mo> </mo> <mtext>mL</mtext> </math> sample of a <math alttext="N H 2 O H" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></math> solution with <math alttext="0.1000 molar H C l" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0.1000</mn> <mo> </mo> <mi>M</mi> <mo> </mo> <mi>HCl</mi> </math>. The student monitors the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mi>pH</mi></math> during the experiment and creates the following titration curve. Selected data are given in the table. (i) Based on the data from the titration experiment, estimate the value of <math alttext="p K sub b" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><msub><mi>K</mi><mi>b</mi></msub></math> for <math alttext="N H 2 O H" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></math>.

(ii) Calculate the molar concentration of the <math alttext="25.00 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25.00</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>mL</mi></math> sample of <math alttext="N H 2 O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.

(iii) In a second trial, using a different <math alttext="25.00 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>25.00</mn><mo> </mo><mi>mL</mi></math> sample of <math alttext="N H 2 O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></math> solution, the volume of <math alttext="H C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi></math> used to reach the equivalence point is greater than in the first trial. The student incorrectly claims that the <math alttext="0.5604 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.5604</mn><mo> </mo><mi>M</mi></math> stock solution of <math alttext="H C l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HCl</mi></math> was used in the second trial instead of the diluted solution. Explain why the student’s claim is incorrect.

<math alttext="3 N H 2 O H, aqueous, reacts to produce N 2, gas, plus N H 3, aqueous, plus 3 H 2 O, liquid, where delta H naught sub reaction equals negative 668 kilojoules per mole sub reaction" overflow="scroll"> <mtable> <mtr> <mtd> <mn>3</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <msub> <mtext>NH</mtext> <mtext>2</mtext> </msub> <mtext>OH</mtext> <mfenced> <mrow> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> </mrow> </mfenced> <mo>→</mo> <msub> <mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mfenced> <mi>g</mi> </mfenced> <mo>+</mo> <msub> <mi>NH</mi> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <mfenced> <mrow> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> </mrow> </mfenced> <mo>+</mo> <mn>3</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <msub> <mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi> <mfenced> <mi>l</mi> </mfenced> </mtd> <mtd> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mtext>Δ</mtext> <msubsup> <mi>H</mi> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mi>x</mi> <mi>n</mi> </mrow> <mtext>∘</mtext> </msubsup> <mo>=</mo> <mo>-</mo> <mn>668</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mi>kJ</mi> <mo>/</mo> <msub> <mi>mol</mi> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mi>x</mi> <mi>n</mi> </mrow> </msub> </mtd> </mtr> </mtable> </math> At elevated temperatures, <math alttext="N H 2 O H, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext><mfenced><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> undergoes decomposition according to the equation shown. (f) If <math alttext="8.00 grams" overflow="scroll"> <mn>8.00</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mtext>g</mtext> </math> of <math alttext="N H 2 O H" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>NH</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub><mtext>OH</mtext></math> decomposes according to the equation above, how much heat, in <math alttext="kilojoules" overflow="scroll"><mi>kJ</mi></math>, is produced?

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
